page.title: 16INDUSTRY 2 - COLYTON Tannery
page.content: The Colyton Tannery is one of only two tanneries left in England that use the traditional oak bark tanning method rather than modern methods using chemicals such as chrome. Leather has to be tanned because an ordinary hide contains about 70% water and would become brittle if it was just allowed to dry out. Colyton Tannery uses about 30 tons of oak bark each year at an average price of Â£30 per ton. Most of its supply comes from the Forest of Dean. The bark is shredded by machine and placed in pits of clean water to release the tannin. This mixture is known as a liquor. For extra hard leather, Turkish Red Oak acorns are used as these contain more tannin. When hides arrive, they are cut up and placed in clean water for a while and then into the first liquor pit.
